be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marsailles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 percent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnightof 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcoutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - CAIRO.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt - - - - - - - -SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE. In connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly 6 p.m., Wednesday for Port Sudan and Saukin direct returning from Suakin evry Wednesday at noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodbidah, Aden. Intermediate steamersdo not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE EUROPEAN OUTLOOK.
div.p: That delicate equipoise, known as the balance of power, has been sadly ont of gear since the downfall of autocracy in Russia. The most striking example of the new state of things in Europe has been the action of Germany in Morocco, and the gloominess of the outlook is fully reflected in one of the telegrams which we publish to-day. Therein we are told that a feeling of apprehension prevails throughout Europe ou the eve of the Morocco Conference, which begins this morning, and that the tone of the Spanish and Italian Press is most pessimists, while even the Berlin newspapers show an unwonted uneasiness at the rumours of Germany's military preparations. It is ridiculous to sneer at these forebodings, since the recent publication of the French Yellow Book on the Morocco question has shown to the world that Germany has within the last few months deliberately risked a most terrible European war on behalf of imaginary rights in Northern Africa, the exiguous nature of which she had already acknowledged. The history of the relations between France and Germany over the Moroccan agreement leave no doubt that the latter Power daring the month of June last was deliberately presenting a pistol to the head of its western neighbour, and that the peace of Europe was gravely endangered without the shadow of a justification. The papers in the Yellow Book begin in March 1931, and show that the anarchy in Morocco, the repeated frontier outrages, and the general ferment on the frontiers of the French possessions in North Africa were producing an absolutely intolerable state of affairs. They show also that on June 23 in that year M. Delcassé admitted to Prince Radolin that France, as mistress of Algeria and Tunis, was bound to preserve an absolutely special position in Morocco. To this admission the German Ambassador replied, "Nothing could be fairer, everybody is in agreement on this point." And, during the three years that followed, the best efforts of French diplomacy were devoted to the maintenance of peace in North West Africa. Of any sinister designs on her part against the integrity of Morocco or against the commercial interests of other nations in that country there is not the smallest trace. Then came the Anglo-French Agreement, which was signed on the 8th of April, 1904. Loss than a fortnight before its promulgation M. Delcassé gave an assurance to Prince Radolin that France might find it necessary to assist the Sultan in the maintenance of the political and territorial status quo in Morocco, bat that, whatever assistance was rendered, the commercial liberty of all nations interested would be rigorously respected. This declaration Prince Radolin pronounced to be quite natural and perfectly reasonable. Prince von Bulow's acceptance of the Anglo-French Agreement, and his admission in the Reichstag that its provisions did not affect the interests if any other Power, will be well remembered.

Daring the whole of 1904, though the Pan Germanic organs began to murmur about German commercial interests being in peril, there was no official sign that the German Government harboured any resentment or felt any uneasiness at the steps which France was preparing to take in Morocco. But as the new year dawned, and as the hopelessness of the Russian entanglement in Manchuria became every day more apparent, there was a sadden change in tone. Germany professed to have discovered that she was being systematically excluded from all participation in the negotiations over Morocco. Prince von Bulow informed the German Chargé d'Affaires at Tangier "that the Imperial Government totally ignored the agreements that had been concluded as regards Morocco, and did not in any way recognise itself as bound in regard to that question." Then came the Kaiser's journey to Tangier, and the speeches of Prince von Bulow, with which we are all familiar. These, we now learn, were supplemented by an amount of hectoring and persistent obstruction which are scarcely paralleled in the relations of Powers that are' nominally friendly. The German Chancellor left no stone untamed to represent to the French Minister of Foreign Affairs that failure to comply with German demands could have only one consequence. The Moroccan question, he declared, was "mauvaise, très mauvaise," and he repeated that one should not linger along a road which " bordered upon a precipice, and even an abyss." Words were used which in international relations posse is an accepted gravity far exceeding that of their usage m ordinary life. France did everything which was possible to avoid any pretext for offence; her attitude carried forbearauce to its extreme limit; finally M. Delcassé was sacrificed on the altar of German Chauvinism, and the negotiations were concluded for the Conference which is to meet to-day at Algeciras. The incident has taught the world in general, and Great Britain in particular, a lesson as to Gorman math ids which can never be forgotten.

The fact stands ont incontestably that for some days, if not for some weeks, daring the summer of 1901 we were on the verge of a conflagration between France and Germany which could not have been isolated, and must have involved sooner or later the whole of Europe. A more grievous blow against civilisation and humanity than the mere contemplation of such a catastrophe is hardly conceivable. Even now it is not apparent how it was averted, and if by any chance it should have been by the influence of England that the conflict was spared, Germany, instead of feeling any resentment, ought to harbour the deepest gratitude to the nation which preserved the peace and saved the world from an incalculable mass of human misery.

But on the contrary we need only expect that malignant hatred that is so often the lot of England because of her altruism, which foreign Powers are so utterly unable to appreciate, and we should prepare ourselves to face the worst. When, therefore, we reflect m the promptitude with which the disaster of Russia was seized upon as an opportunity for the humiliation of her ally ; whoa we consider the utter disregard of previous utterances and policy which characterise the whole of the German intervention in Morocco; and when we appreciate the light-heartedness with which Germany provokes a terrible European débâcle, it is difficult for ns to contemplate 'he future without apprehension and to look forward to the conference, who e sittings begin this morning, without a certain amount of alarm.

div.head: Military Tournament.
div.p: The Royal Military Tournament will take place on the 31at inst. at Ghezireh.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The mail will close at the G. P. 0., Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m. on Sunday.

div.head: National Hotel,
div.p: The Bracale orchestra will play for dinner at the National Hotel, Cairo, on Saturday.

div.head: Revue d'Egypte et d'Orient.
div.p: The December issue of this excellent little local publication is as foil and as interesting as its predecessors.

div.head: Red Sea Lighthouses.
div.p: We have received a parcel of literature from Mr. R. Kuster for the use of the English keepers of the Red Sea lighthouses.

div.head: Anniversaries.
div.p: To-day is the twentieth anniversary of the fall of Omdurman. On the 5th January, 1899. the Gordon College was founded at Khartoum.

div.head: A Red Sea Find.
div.p: A new species of worm has been discovered lately on the shores of the Red Sea. It is a Pontodrilus.

div.head: Cinema Parisien.
div.p: By request, there will until further notice be two exhibitions of the Cinema Parisien, from 5 to 8 p.m. and from 9 p.m. to midnight, without interruption.

div.head: New Khédivial Hotel.
div.p: The new wing of the New Khédivial Hotel, Alexandria, is now fini-bed and is being furnished. Thirty rooms are now ready and a total of sixty new rooms will be ready in two months' time.

div.head: General Holidays.
div.p: All Government Departments and offices will be closed on the 8th inst., on the occasion of the anniversary of the Khedive's accession, and on the 11th inst., on the occasion of the departure, of the Mahmal.

div.head: Pilgrim Hospital.
div.p: The Sultan has ordered a hospital of 120 beds to be constructed at Ma'àn, on the Hedjaz railway. A building is to be commenced immediately and meantime a tent hospital will supply the needs of the garrison and of the pilgrims.

div.head: Transport.
div.p: The transport Sicilia, which is due at Port Said on the 9th inst., will embark a number of details of the Army of Occupation for passage to England. Those from Alexandria will leave by the 3.40 p.m. train and those from Cairo by the 6.15 p.m. train on the 8th inst.

div.head: The Egyptian Elephant.
div.p: There is a highly interesting account in Professor Ray Lankester's new book on extinct animals of the history of the elephant as disclosed. by the remarkable fossils discovered in recent years by Dr. Andrews and Mr. Beadnell, in the Eocene deposits of the Fayoum district, and known as Palæomastodon and Meri therium, the latter representing a very early ancestral type, a rather pig-like animal, yet foreshadowing in many ways the elephant to be.

div.head: Coptic Manuscripts.
div.p: A catalogue of the Coptic Manuscripts in the British Museum has been published by Mr. W. E. Crum. The collection described in this catalogue consists of MSS. in the Sa'idic, Middle Egyptian, and Bohairic dialects of Coptic. Of these, the first group comes mainly from the White Monastery at Ahmin, the second mainly from the Fayoum, and the third from the Nitrian monasteries. This is the first published catalogue which embraces MSS., both literary and non-literary, in all these idioms.

div.head: OBITUARY.
div.p: GEORGE OGILVY HAIG.

Mr. George Ogilvy Haig, who died on Sunday week, was greatly interested in Egyptian mining. He was a director of the Egyptian Gold and Gem Syndicate Limited, and of the Egyptian Sudan Minerals, Limited, and was well known in Cairo. He died at Chester under very sad circumstances. Mr. and Mrs. Haig left 65, Brook-street on Saturday afternoon to spend Christmas with Mr. Haig's sister in Dublin, breaking the journey at Chester. That night Mr. Haig felt unwell, but there wore no serious symptoms until he was dressing in the morning, when ptomaine poisoning declared itself in a most virulent form, and in two hours he was dead.

Mr. George Haig was the fourth son of Mr. John Haig, of Cameron Bridge, Fife, N B. He married nine years ago the daughter of the late Mr. William Astor, of New York. His youngest brother is General Douglas Haig. The Haigs belong to the well-known Haigs of Bemerside, of whom Thomas the Rhymer in the thirteenth century prophesied, "Tyde what may betyde, Haig shall be Haig of Bemerside." So far the prophecy bus been fulfilled, and, considering the size and affluence of the family, there is no sign as yet of any failure of fulfilment.

div.head: THE GENERAL ELECTION. LIBERAL PROSPECTS DAMAGED.
div.p: The last week has shown that Liberal prospects of a return at the General Election have been considerably damaged.

div.head: LONDON'S UNDERGROUND RAILWAYS.
div.p: Mr. Edgar Speyer has accepted the chairmanship of the Underground Electric Railways in succession to the late Mr. R. Yerkes. Sir George Gibb, general manager of the North Eastern Railway, becomes vice chairman and managing director of the Metropolitan and District Railway.

div.head: DEUTSCHE ORIENT BANK.
div.p: The constituting assembly of the Deutsche Orient Bank wot held in Berlin yesterday.

div.head: CHINESE LABOUR IN THE RAND.
div.p: It is reported that Lord Selborne, High Commissioner for South Africa, stated that if his signature to the pending contracts for the importation of Chinese into the Rand are not honoured by the Imperial Government he will resign his Office. Lord Elgin has agreed to the contracts being fulfilled.

div.head: ARMY REFORM.
div.p: Mr. Haldane, the new Secretary for War, delivered a speech in the City last night in which he raised the question of the Army outside the sphere of party politics. The speech which was a frank acknowledgment that there was room for improvement and contained a suggestion that he intended to do for the Army what Admiral Fisher hid done for the Navy, on reconstruction lines which would bring it up to the highest quality of efficiency and mobility, and his response to the spirit of the Volunteers, mark him as a statesman of the first class.

div.head: MINISTRY OF JUSTICE.
div.p: The Budget of the Ministry of Justice, which in 1905 was fixed at LE 504,200, has been railed to L.E. 534.737, showing an increase of LE 80,537. Of this increase, L.E. 13,103 is attributable to the Mixed Tribunals, and L.E 16,142 to the Native Tribunals.

There is an increase of L.E. 584 in the expenses of Central Administration. A new post of interpreter bas been created in view of the increasing amount of English work; some increases of salary have been granted.

Under the beading of Mixed Tribunals the increase is mainly attributable t) the creation of new posts, and to the arrangement instituted in 1905, by which the 2 % fee to greffiers and the travelling expenses of huissiers are no longer deducted from the receipts of the tribunals.
Provision has been made for the appoint ment of an additional native Judge of the Court of Appeal.

An additional foreign Judge of First Instance will also be appointed, end will be attached to the Tribunal of Alexandria The Budget of 1905 provided for 11 Judges of First Instance for Cairo, and 11 for Alexandria: but it has been found absolutely necessary to attach 12 Judges to the Cairo Tribunal, and there have thus been only 10 available for Alexandria. Experience has shown that another Judge at Alexandria is needed.

The increased volume of business coming before the Tribunals of Cairo and Alexandria has necessitated a corresponding increase in the number of employés attached to those tribunals, and over 30 new posts have been created.

The amount allowed in the Budget of 1905 for expenses formerly paid directly ont of the receipts of the tribunals has been found to be insufficient, and an increase of LE 3,569 is granted on this account
The pay of "hors cadre" employés has been raised.

The system of Native Assize Courts has now been in operation in Cairo and Lower Egypt fir nearly a year, and appears to be a decided success The system will be extended to Upper Egypt from the beginning of 1906, and provision has been made for meeting the cost of his extension. An additional native Judge of the Court of Appeal will be appointed, and will be available for Assize work; the extension will necessitate a considerable increase in the costs of transport travelling allowances and indemnities of the Judges, and additional copying clerks have to be engaged.

The salaries of the Avocat-Général and of the European Inspectors of the Parquet bave been raised, and an additional native Inspector of the Parquet will be appointed. The work required of the medical expert attached to the Parquet has become too heavy for one man, and provision is made for the appointment of an assistant.

As in the case of tin Mixed Tribunals, it has been found that the sum allotted for expenses formerly paid directly out of receipts is insufficient: an additional sum of LE 6,500 has been provided to meet these expenses.

div.head: NEW DOCTORS' FEES.
div.p: LAST NIGHT'S MEETING.
MASS MEETING TO BE HELD.

Yesterday evening, as announced, a meeting was held at Alexandria to protest against the enormous increase in the fees of medical practitioners, as decreed by the recent decision of the Medical Council of Alexandria. There was a fair attendance of persons and a number of speeches were made on the subject of the hardships which this increase will inflict on the poorer classes of the community, especially in the case of the inhabitants of the city itself, where the fees have been doubled, from 5 francs to 10 francs for each visit to the doctor. It was eventually decided to summon another meeting for Friday next, when the following propositions will be discussed and put to the vote:
That a committee shall be appointed with a view to interviewing the members of the Medical Council of Alexandria and pointing out to those gentlemen the injustice of their recent decision.

That a mass meeting should be organised, to be held in a local theatre, for the purpose of protesting on behalf of all the inhabitants of Alexandria and Ramleh against the extortions of local medical practitioners.

div.head: THE DIPHTHERIA EPIDEMIC AT ZEITOUN.
div.p: Drs. Bitter and Dreyer have made an interesting official statement relating to the outbreak of diphtheria at Zeitoun. It appears that the first case was reported on December 23, when a child died. Three more cases were noted on the 28th, and Drs. Dreyer and d'Andrea visited all cases reported and inoculated children who were known to have been in contact with the three children actually ill, who were also inoculated with serum. In one case the remedy came too late, the other two are now convalescent. On the following day seven new cases were reported, six of which proved fatal. No cases were reported after January 1, the total death-roll amounting to eight out of twelve cases.

The anti-toxin employed was fresh Behring serum, which is universally regarded as the best in existence. Rigorous measures have been taken to prevent the spread of the epidemic and the schools will be closed till farther notice.

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE.
div.p: Several very auspicious ewes of bovine typhus have been reported from the Fayoum, but were promptly dealt with by the Veterinary Department of the Public Health Administration.

div.head: NEW HOSPITAL AT GALIOUB
div.p: Mohamed Shawarby Pacha, a member of tin Legislative Council and a wealthy notable of Galioubish province, has built a hospital at Galioub at his own expense. He has spent over L.E 5,000 on the building and endowed the hospital with 200 feddans of land, which will yield an income of from L.E. 1,500 to LE. 2,000 per annum. The Pacha has informed the Sanitary Department of the completion of the building. The new hospital will be officially opened shortly.

div.head: CHARITY FETE.
div.p: The annual charity fête organised in Cairo by the ladies of the Diplomatic Corps will take place about the beginning of March and will be in aid of the Société Internationale Philanthropique du Caire. The organisers are the Countess of Cromer, Mme Van der Does de Villebois, the Countess A. de Zogheb, and Mme Rucker-Jenisch. The usual lottery will be held, and the following is the first list of prizes, with the names of their donors: —

div.head: CALENDARS FOR 1906
div.p: Calendars, almanacks, and other useful means of advertising are, as usual, much in in evidence at this time of year. The Phoenix Assurance Company is distributing a useful calendar and a steel paper knife, besides some convenient pocket diaries, to its many clients in Egypt. The Royal Insurance Company is presenting blotting pads, while the memento of the Guardian Assurance Company is an elegant notebook. Artistic almanacks are being distributed by the Deutsche Levante Lane, the Yorkshire Insurance Company, the Ellerman and Papayanni Lines, Royal Insurance Company, Messrs. Aziz & Dorés, Mr. L Schuler, the Trans-Atlantic Fire Insurance Company of Hamburg, etc. The Florio-Rubattino Company is giving a very useful New Year's gift in the shape of a hand-blotter. Messrs. E D. Protopapas & Co. are issuing a very fine office almanack.

div.head: FINANCIAL ADVISER'S NOTE.
div.p: THE SPECULATION BOGEY.
CRITICISMS BY OUR READERS.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,—"An Admirer of the British Administration" strikes the right nail on the head in pointing oat that the notes of warning constancy sounded by our administrators have the effect of keeping out of Egypt only the British investor; I however think that he might have worded his protest more strongly. No doubt in a measure the prosperity of Egypt is due to the wise administration of Lord Cromer, and more so to the able Irrigation engineers who have greatly improved our water supply, but after all is said and done, the real factors are the wonderful fertility or the soil and the untiring industry of the fellah.

The Press of England in the first instance, and latterly that of the world, has so extolled our British administrators that they in their turn have been brought to believe they are beings beyond or out of, the common order of humanity, competent to express an infallible opinion on any and every subject, hence as a result these grandmotherly efforts which are periodically made to pat down what they consider gambling or over-speculation, which only succeed in adversely affecting legitimate business for a short time.

The European community in Egypt being small, ever one knows what everybody is doing, consequently if any lucky Government official possessing a small amount of capital and the sense to invest it in local securities, makes a legitimate profit, the news speedily circulates and our high administrators shake their wise heads and say "we mast put a stop to gambling md speculation."

"Admirer is quite right when he says that there is less commercial gambling in Egypt than in most countries, but he is wrong in attributing this to the want of a '''term market" in stocks and shares, the reason is that there are and have been daring the past few years and will continue to exist for many years to come, plenty of opportunities of making handsome profits by purchasing lands both agricultural and building, stocks and shares, and hiding the same for a rapid and legitimate rise consequently the inducement to gamble is lacking.
The only inflated value in Egypt is perhaps the estimation in which some of our worthy administrators hold themselves. — I beg to remain, Sir, etc.,
"ANGLO-EGYPTIAN."
Cairo, January 4.

div.head: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
div.p: Will your correspondent who writes under the name of "An Admirer of the British Administration in Egypt" kindly mention the names of a tow towns of lees importance than Cairo or Alexandria where values of building sites are higher than in those named above? It "Admirer" is right which I very much doubt, it will be the duty of the Financial Adviser to withdraw the sweeping assertions made in his Budget Note, but until that is proved I think Sir Vincent Corbett has rendered a public service in warning the unsuspecting British Public against the Egyptian land speculator who is baying up at unheard-of priors every available plot of land.—I am, Sir, etc.
"FAIR PLAY"
Cairo, 4th January.

div.head: NATIVE FEELING.
div.p: AN ALARMIST VIEWPOINT.
To THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,—Since the recent trouble at Alexandria I have endeavoured by various methods to ascertain what feeling, if any, exists in the provinces are to an anti-Christian movement. It is obvions that any attempt of this sort on the part of a foreigner and a Christian is-fraught with many difficulties, and that anyone looking for trouble might imagine he had found it where none really existed. In common with meet people who live and work in the provinces I was strongly of opinion that no danger was to be looked for from the fellaheen and lashed class generally, but I regret to say I have bad to alter my opinion.

I find that the "barb el deen" is the one topic of conversation among them. The younger men are faying "Why should we wait for the order; let us begin." The older men who look to the Sultan say, "Wait, he will give the word when all is ready." They know all about the trouble in Macedonia and they believe that the faith is in danger in Morocco and that the time is come to make one last decisive stand against ever-encroaching Christianity.

They reason thus. Against Alexandria we cannot do ouch as there are English ships which we cannot do much and they are land many men, but at Cairo, where there are many Christians and few soldiers, we can do much, and even if the go to extremes we shall be able eventually to make them give in and so compel then to leave the country, and in the provinces we can do what we like. When all the Mohamedan world is fighting the last great fight for the faith how shall the Christians overcome us, will not God and the Prophet give us the victory?

This, Sir I affirm, is the state of affairs at the present moment, bat the spark that shall start the blaze is happily lacking at the time. But when the spark is kindled the conflagration will not be a small one. The less that is said and the more precautions that are taken in an affair of this sort the better. — Yours, etc.,
"PROVINCIAL."

div.head: ALEXANDRIA'S TRANQUILLITY.
div.p: AFTER THE RIOT.
NOTABLE DECREASE IN CRIME.

One result of the recent riot at Alexandria has been the extraordinary good order now prevailing in the city. Petty cases in the local police courts have suddenly decreased by about 80 per cent. Where there used to be 70 cases of "delits" and "contraventions" in the courts, now there are only 18 such cases and even less per diem. In the Menshieh Court, at the last sitting, there was only one case. The lower classes of the population have, by the wholesale arrests and the incarceration of nearly 100 of the rioters, been taught a lesson, and their inclinations to rowdiness has in consequence been considerably checked.

div.head: THE NILE SEASON.
div.p: The Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotel Company anticipate a very good season. Their line is even popular among Royalty, which is proved by the fact that the special steamer Niagara has been chartered by her Royal Highness Princess Louise of Battenberg and a distinguished party for a lengthy Nile trip. The Niagara will start with the Royal party on January 21.
The S. S. Columbia has also been specially chaptered by Sir George Cooper, Bart, who with a party of friends will start from Cairo on January 29.
Herr von Papp, member of the Hungarian Parliament, with his sister, Miss Papp, have arranged to leave by the Anglo-American Company's steamer Puritan.

div.head: THE NEW NILE BRIDGE.
div.p: The Finance Ministry has opened a credit of LE. 50.000 for the expropriation of the lands necessary for widening Boulac-road from the Halim Buildings and the Grand Continental Hotel up to the Nile at the point where the new bridge is to he constructed.

A special committee of engineers has been appointed to examine the scheme. The bridge and the roadway will he twenty metres broad and the Cairo Tramway Company will he authorized to establish a line of trams over the bridge.

div.head: RUMOURED SALE OF PALACE.
div.p: It is rumoured that the Kasr el Ali Palace and the neighbouring ground owned by H.H. Prince Mohamed Ibrahim have been sold for LE 600,000.

div.head: CAIRO FETES.
div.p: The Cairo Committee of Fetes have drawn up the following programme for the season :

There will be a ball, by invitation only, at Shepheard's on the 17th inst. Early in February there will ha a Ridotto, where rose dominoes will be "de rigueur" for ladies and mauve dominoes for men, at the Savoy Hotel. The Battle of Flowers will take place on February 18, and the Corso on the 23rd February. The dates of a children's hall and a Beauty Show are not yet fixed.

div.head: CONSULAR CHANGES.
div.p: The recent rupture in the relations between the dual kingdoms of Scandinavia has led to some changes in the consular representatives of Sweden and Norway in Egypt.
Mr. Belinfante-Ostberg, late Diplomatic Agent and Consul General for Sweden and Norway, remains the representative of the former Power only.
Mr. Henry Barker, late Swedish and Norwegian Consul at Alexandria, has resigned his position in regard to Sweden and has been promoted Consul-General for Norway in Egypt.
Mr. Aug. de Silfwerhjelm, commercial agent of the Swedish Government, has been appointed acting Vice-Consul of Sweden in Alexandria.

div.head: MINISTRY OF PUBLIC WORKS.
div.p: Mr. A. Marcom, director of works to the Delta Barrage, has been transferred to the 1st Circle of Irrigation.
Mr. Trevor Dennis has been appointed 3rd class surveyor of contracts to the Zifta Circle.
Messrs. S.R. Chichester, Oswald. L Proades, and John Murray have been appointed 3rd class surveyors of contracts to the 3rd, 2nd, and 4th Circles respectively.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H. R. R. Prince William of Sweden is probably leaving Alexandria for Cairo tomorrow.

The Bishop of Hereford is coming to Egypt early this month on a visit to his son, Captain Percival, D.S.O., who is serving in the Egyptian Army, and expects to be absent from England until the end of February.
We are pleased to announce that the Hon. Evelyn Baring passed a fairly good night, and his condition is as satisfactory as can be expected.

Boghos Pacha Nubar gave a most successful soirée on Wednesday evening at which Cairo society was brilliantly represented. M. Coquelin Cadet and Mlle Moreno charmed all who were present by a series of dialogues, monologues, and recitations, and as both were in their best form, the audience enjoyed a dramatic entertainment of the first order. The programme consisted of the following pieces : 1. "Democrite," fragments by J. Raynard ; 2. "En Wagon," by Verconsin ; 3. "Une Valse," monologue ; 4. Recitation of verses by Mlle Moreno ; 5. Monologues by Coquelin Cadet. A ball followed the dramatic entertainment and dancing lasted till a late hour, when the guests departed delighted by one of thé most brilliant soirées recently given in Cairo.
We are glad to hear that there is a decided improvement in Mme Vayssié's condition.
Dr. Sabri Farah has been authorised practise in Egypt.

Amongst the latest arrivals at the Eastern Exchange Hotel, Port Said, are Mr. J. I. Carver, Miss Carver, Mr. R. H. Parker, Boroin Dobinesky and family, Miss Paula Fischer, Mr. N. Maclaren, Col. E. Welchman, Mrs. Welchman, Mrs. J. C. Mills, Mr. Mills, Miss M. S. Tucker, Dumrucheer Bey, Mr. A. J. Lowe, Mr. G.W.Y. Little, Mrs. G. P. Chatto.

div.head: BOMB FOUND NEAR SUEZ CANAL OFFICES.
div.p: The porter at the offices occupied by the Suez Canal Company in Paris opened the carriage entrance the other morning at 8 o'clock, when he noticed a cone-shaped object lying on the ground against the wall underneath the bell. He ran for the police commissary of the district, who sent four officials to mount guard round the bomb, and shortly afterwards M. Girard, director of the Municipal laboratory, sent a motor-car for the bomb and had it removed for examination.

div.head: ABBASSIEH DESERT OASIS.
div.p: Boghos Pacha Nobar has forwarded to the Ministry of Public Works the plans for the first portion of the tramway line which is to unite Cairo with the Abbassieh Desert Oasis.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL DECORATIONS.
div.p: The Khedive has conferred the following decorations -Medjidieh (1st class), Scander Pacha Fehmy.
Osmanieh (2nd class), Mr. Cotteril, ex-chief engineer of the State Railways.
Salisaah, Mutualli Eff. Mohamed, ex-station master of Wasta.

div.head: LOCAL METEOROLOGY.
div.p: The Survey Department announces that the following changes will he made in the publication of the meteorological observations of Egypt and the Sudan, commencing this month.
1. The daily observations made at climatological stations will no longer be published monthly, but will be included in the annual report.

2. The monthly weather summary will be enlarged, and will include additional stations so as to connect the Egyptian and Sudan area with those of India and Europe, and will give a detailed summary of the climate of the month, together with the mean and extreme values of the principal meteorological phenomena.

3. The annual report will include:- (a) An account of the climate of the year in Egypt and the Sudan ; (b) The hourly observations made at the Helouan Observatory; (c) The daily observations made at the climatological stations ; (d) The measurements of rainfall and the river gauge readings of the Nile.

div.head:
MOROCCO CONFERENCE.
APPREHENSIVE FEELING.
CONTINENTAL PRESS PESSIMISTIC.

div.p: A renewed feeling of apprehensiveness prevails on the eve of the Morocco Conference. The Spanish and Italian Press are most pessimistic, and the latter is remarkable for a distinct tone of hostility to Germany. Even the Berlin newspapers dispute the official assurances, being uneasy owing to rumours of German military preparations. (Reuter)
Big. Visconti-Venosta will represent Italy at the Algesiras Conference.
(Havas)

A remarkable semi-official statement issued here declares that the United States, by virtue of having wiped out piracy, and having concluded the first treaty with the Barbary States, have a right superior to any European State in deciding critical questions at the Morocco Conference. (Reuter)

No Unionist candidates have been nominated for twenty-nine constituencies, and it is probable that more Liberals than Unionists will be returned unopposed, thus reversing the conditions of the last election. The Liberals have accepted the Labour candidates in 42 constituencies, while Labourites oppose Liberals or Unionists in 34.
(Reuter)

In an electoral address, Mr. H. Gladstone reiterates the Government's desire to develop the Irish policy of the late Government, and so enable Irishmen to be directly associated with the management of purely Irish affairs. No proposal for a legislative parliament for Ireland can be introduced during the coming parliament.

Speaking at Manchester, Mr. Churchill said that the Government would not continue in office unless it obtained a substantial majority, enabling it to maintain itself with dignity and honour in the Commons.
(Reuter)

div.head:
RUSSIA QUIET AGAIN.
WORK RESUMED EVERYWHERE.

div.p: Work is being resumed everywhere. Arrests continue in Moscow. The Tsar has thanked the troops for their faithful services.
(Reuter)
The aspect of the city has become normal again. The damage caused by the rising is estimated at 150 million roubles.
(Havas)
M. Witte and Count Lamsdorff have expressed themselves as being much surprised at the letter of Admiral Rodjestvensky.

Admiral Rodjestvensky in a communication to the "Novoye Vremya" explains that the permission given by the Ministry of Marine to publish his letter, did not imply the Minister's agreement with the views therein expressed. The allusion to Great Britain was merely the Admiral's private opinion.
(Reuter)

div.head: EGYPT'S EXAMPLE TO U.S.A.
div.p: BANK FOR THE PHILLIPINES

The United States has determined to follow the example of Egypt in creating an Agricultural Bank for the Philippine Islands. A very full account of the operations of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt is contained in the report of E. W. Kemmerer, chief of the currency division of the treasury, in the matter of the establishment of an agricultural bank in the islands. Mr. Kemmerer deals with the Egyptian plan of loaning money to agriculturists in great detail and then proceeds to give an account of the draft bill containing the plan proposed for the Philippines. The bill largely explains itself, and requires little comment. The plan proposed is an attempt to adjust the Egyptian scheme to Philippine conditions. Many features of the bill, however, are adapted from provisions in the laws governing the principal agricultural banks of Europe, copies of which are given in the exhibits of this report. The bill contains comparatively few original features, and with few exceptions the provisions of the bill in their essentials have been for many years in successful operation in one or more European countries.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: Messrs. Gibson and Bredin, of Liverpool, writing on the 29th ult., remark :—

The market this week has been doll and featureless with only minor fluctuations and with little or no new business doing pending the completion of the holidays. We are not in favour of buying cotton at present prices except for very short views, as we still consider the situation dangerous although there has been considerable liquidation of contracts in New York during this week ; we are advised by our correspondents in the South that cotton is accumulating at the ports and interior towns in large quantities, and unless the stringency in the money market eases very considerably, we doubt the power of the factors and planters to hold the balance of their crop, as they will shortly begin to require money for preparations for planting.
There is another Ginners Report due on the 8th prox. which is expected to show 9,800,000 ginned to the 1st January.

Theodore Price of New York, in his latest circular, maintains that this year there has been more cotton he'd in the seed and on the plantations than ever, and maintains his estimate that the commercial crop will be 11 millions or over.

div.head: JEWS AND THE JEWISH PERIL.
div.p: A remarkable and instructive article by a learned Hebrew writer, Dr. Singer, the Editor-in-Chief of the "Jewish Encyclopaedia," appears in the current "North American Review." Dr. Singer combats the view, held by many Americans, that there is a Jewish peril, as well as a Yellow peril ; that Christian civilisation, in fact, may be in danger from the multiplication of the Hebrew races. It is true that there is hardly a country under the sun where Jews are not to be found, bat the whole Jewish population of the world does not much exceed 11,000,000. It is relatively large in tome parts of the United States, and the Jews in New York City have increased to three-quarters of a million, from 50,000 only a quarter of a century ago. But even snob a fact as that need not alarm the most nervous, for the Jews, says Dr. Singer, so fir from being, as they are popularly imagined to be, a wealthy community, are "the poorest conglomeration of human beings on the earth." Even in London, where the Hebrew race has free scope for commercial enterprise and money-making, there is a very large proportion of poor. In 1883 the total Jewish population of our metropolis was 47,000 of whom over 11,000—that is to say about 28 per cent—were dependent on the charity of their co religionists.

div.head: AN EGYPTIAN FUNERAL.
div.p: INTERESTING DESCRIPTION OF BURIAL CEREMONIES.

Egypt has been styled "the laud of the dead," and in many respects this is true. No nation of the past or present so constantly brings death before us. It is from the tombs, the "eternal houses" of the dead, that we learn the minutest details of the living Egypt of long centuries ago. The chief life rature of Nile-land is the "Book of the Dead," her pyramids are the tombs of her oldest raiera, her temples, in most oases, the mortuary chapels of kings or gods. In a land so devoted to eschatology, to the great hereafter, it is but natural to expect that a funeral service of an interesting character moat have been in use. The funeral service of the Egyptians is certainly the oldest in the world; and, what is more remarkable, it varied but slightly in its details from the earliest times until long after the Christian era. It probably assumed its most elaborate form during the time of the Theban hierarchy of the Eighteenth and Nineteenth Dynasties, and this is elaborately set before us in the papyri of the period. A splendid enlargement of the funeral vignette of the Papyrus Ani is now exhibited on the walls of the First Egyptian Room at the British Museum. Here we see the funeral ritual in its most ornate form, but from the funeral stele of the people we are able to trace it back to its most primitive form.

This has been most clearly worked out by M. Moret, in his study of the divine character of the Pharaoh, and an extremely interesting evolution of ritual is revealed. On the faneral stele the deceased is attended by a number of his relatives. Among those the most important was "the eldest son," or, as is more frequently called, "the son who loves." It was the duty of the eldest son to minister at the interment of his father, as we read in a book of instructions to the Egyptian youth. "Forget not to minister the funeral offerings at the tomb of thy father and mother, that thy son may do the same for thee." Next in importance to the eldest son was the "wife his beloved," often really his sister, according to the Egyptian system—for the words sister and wife become synonymous. She is often represented weeping at the feet of the mummy, or in earlier examples seated beside her husband. This latter is the attitude adopted in some of the finest examples of Egyptian art, such as the statues of Rshotep and Nefert. The wife's sister and her daughter often form members of the group. Then come the other children, the friends and acquaintances, and the servant, who attends on the group which gathered round the grave, or assembled before the rock-cut tomb; and the ceremony of whatever kind it was, was essentially a family one.

In course of time, when the priestly hierarchy replaced the family or patriarchal ceremony new elements were introduced. The functions of the eldest son were usurped by the sem, or ministrant priest, who performed the semi-magical ritual at the grave. In the painting of the funeral of Ani he is represented as walking backwards before the hier-censing it or sprinkling it with holy water, a custom which has survived to the present day. On either side of the sledge on which the mummy is placed, kneel two women, sometimes the wife and daughter of the dead, as in the primitive ceremony, but now representative of divine personages. Assisting the priest was the servant, now raised to the position of server at the altar, erected before the tomb, and behind them clad in a white garment astonishingly like a surplice, stands the reader, or reciter, who, from a papyrus book, reads the funeral service and directs the various movements of those taking part in the ceremony.

Before the door of the tomb the mummy is placed, while the wife or her representative kneels at the feet washing them with her tears and wiping them with her hair. In the papyrus of Hunifer, an enlargement of which is exhibited in the next room, we see his wife and daughter thus parting with the body. The ritual is no longer that of the family function of primitive times, it is all symbolical of the funeral of Osiris, with whom the decreased is identified. The ministrant priest represents Horus, the eldest son of Osiris-who minister at his father's grave. The reader or director is the all-wise god Thoth. The friends are the four children of Horus, and the wife and sister are representatives of the two faithful divine sisters, who wait ever on their lord and master Osiris. In the Osirian funeral ritual of the Egyptians, which remained in use certainly until the third century of our era, and according to which millions were committed to the "hidden land," no character are more interesting than these two divine sisters, Isis and Nephthys.

These two sisters, Isis the sister wife, and Nephthys, or, to give her Egyptian Nebt-Hit, "the house lady," are the ministering ones to the god-man Orisis. As we learn from the festival songs of these goddesses, it is to their house that he comes to rest. "Nephthys, who is called the housekeeper of the gods," ministers to his wants. The two goddesses gather spices and unguents, the balms of Arabia or Persia, linen and wax, with which they prepare for his burial, bringing them, as we are told, "to his rock-cut tomb." They weep with the weeping women over his body, wiping away the impurities therefrom with their hair. So we see what a curious parallel their duties present to those of Mary and Martha in the New Testament. We see that many of the features of the Osirian funeral ceremony have survived to this day, and it is an excellent idea of Dr. Budge to place these fine enlargements in the galleries of the Museum which are devoted to the remains of the dead of ancient Egypt. It may not be out of place to record here an appreciation of the excellent arrangements now found in the Egyptian Section of the British Museum. Twenty years ago, it was a chaos; now it is a great educational exhibition. Section follows section in regular sequence, and the student or teacher can really now read, mark, learn, and inwardly digest the wonderful story of Nileland.

div.head: EDUCATION IN THE LEVANT.
div.p: THE SYRIAN PROTESTANT COLLEGE AT BEYROUT.

To everybody who has sojourned in the beautiful Bay of Beyrout "the College," with its magnificent background of the Lebanon range, which towers to the height of 8,000ft., is familiar. For the benefit of those who have not visited the busy Syrian port be it explained that "the College" is the Syrian Protestant College, whose solid stone buildings give a look of permanence which as a matter of fact is not belied by its history ; for it is near celebrating the 40th anniversary of its birthday. Some of those who know the East mast have been surprised when in 1866 its commencement, under the sway of not the least notable member of the distinguished American missionary family of Bliss, was recorded. Their surprise will not be lessened on learning that it has never been so strong as it is at present, in spite of the fact that the determination of its founders, that its lines should only be Protestant in the broadest sense, has been firmly adhered to. What this means will be understood when it is said that the students include Greek Orthodox Churchmen, Protestants, Moslems, Jews, Druses, and Roman Catholic, and when it is remembered how bitter certain sectarian differences tend to become in the East—indeed, not in the East alone. And there are even more nationalities than sects represented. From the Black Sea to the Sudan, from Egypt and Greece to Persia there is scarcely a nationality or sub-nationality but is represented at the service which is held daily in the afternoon. A wonderful gathering the service is. Here are young men not only of nationalities which have often been arrayed against each other, but of religious beliefs irreconcilably opposed. How can the Moslem sing and pray with the Christian? The answer is that he does, thanks to the broad Christian spirit of the institution. The teaching and administrative staff is little less remarkable in its representation of nationalities than the students' roll Britons and Americans, two branches of one family, number thirty-three ont of sixty-three. The remaining thirty are Syrians (no fewer than twenty), Germans, Italians, Greek, Swiss, and Armenians.

If the Beyrout College were compared in one respect with the enterprise of the great London philanthropist who is just dead the comparison might stand. True, it would not relate to physical needs. These in the Eastern land are few and easily supplied. But intellectually, morally, spiritually, a vast proportion of the peoples in and about Syria would be in as bad a case as the London street-boy, before the day of Dr. Barnardo, was in all these respects and physically also. There are about seven hundred students on the roll to-day. Since the inauguration of the college fully a thousand graduates have passed from it to occupy some of the most important positions in the community – such as those of physicians (civil and military), lawyers, doctors, judges, teachers, preachers, editors, authors, merchants.

The chief medium of instruction is English, and to attend a service or a lecture, and note the dark, earnest faces, and hear the students singing or speaking the tongue of Milton and Shakespeare, is to feel in presence of an Imperialism upon the ultimate consequences of which it is impossible to ponder without a thrill of hope and of thankfulness. That the politico-religious leaders of Moslem thought are alive to the nature of these consequences needs scarcely to be insisted upon, and although hitherto thanks as well to the wide-mindedness of more than one highly-placed servant of the Sultan as to the tact of the authorities of the college, matters have proceeded smoothly, the fate of the institution would not be long in doubt but for its connection with Anglo-Saxon Powers. There are six departments, and the tuition fees are £10 per term in the Departments of Commerce, Pharmacy, and Medicine, £5 in the Collegiate and Preparatory Departments. Board costs £12 per year – there are two terms per year, the year beginning in October and ending in July – which includes cost of sleeping accomodation. One hears of affecting instances of the privations which students and their relatives undergo in order to provide these modest amounts; nor are affecting instances of gratitude to the alma mater unknown. The other day a graduate settled at Bloemfoutein established two scholoarships as an acknowledgment of his own debt.

While English, as stated, is the language of instruction in all departments there are thorough courses in French, German, Turkish, and, of course, Arabic. The grounds are fine and spacious – nearly forty acres in all – and physical exercise is given by a trained instructor. Field day – the day of the annual sports – is an institution not easily to be forgotten, and when the events are wound up with a game of Association football, and one hears the game cries out, or, rather, yelled, in English one almost feels inclined to offer a tributary yell oneself. There are over forty baths and a properly, if modestly, equipped hospital. In this connection it is to be added that the college is making a special effort to cope locally with that scourge of the East – ophthalmia – with which object a hospital wing to cost £1,000 is being taken in hand. An English traveller who visited the college for the first time not long ago was so impressed with all he saw and heard that he volunteered a contribution of a hundred guineas to encourage the prompt establishment of the sorely-eneded ophthalmic hospital.

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: A vacancy for a Dispenser in the Sudan Department will shortly occur at Omdurman. Applicants should apply on 3 P.T. stamped paper, to the Director of Sudan Medical Department, Khartoum, stating age, nationality, etc.
Two certificates of character and professional qualifications, one by a British known resident if possible, should accompany the application. The applicant should be unmarried.

The salary commences at L.B. 16 per month. There are periodical increases if service satisfactory. The first year's service is on probation. The person may come under the Sudan Government Pension Law, after the expiration of one year's satisfactory service.
(Signed), J. B. Christopherson.
27068-3-1 Senior Medical Inspector, S.G.

div.head: Post Office Notice.
div.p: The continual increase in the demand for house-to-house delivery in Cairo and Alexandria renders it absolutely necessary that all I persons in these towns desirous of such delivery shill have the number of the house and name of the street in which they live indicated on their correspondence. Should by any chance a street be unnamed, then the quarter of the town in which it is situated must be indicated.
Attention to these instructions is imperative to avoid delay and errors in the delivery of correspondence.

div.head: OUR PARIS LETTER.
div.p: Paris, December 28.

Christmas in over, and in London the work of the week is beginning again. But here in Paris Christmas has been but the flash in the pan of the reveillon feasting, the hors d'aeuvre which is the prelude for the real festival, "The Day of the Year," as Parisians call the 1st of January. To one class of society "In jour do Tan" has Ions terrors than it used to have, for the motor car has at last made it possible for the diner out to got through his round of visits within the time proscribed by the tenets of "cette bonne dame Grundy." Cabs used to be not only a luxury in Paris on the 1st of January—it was almost impossible to hire one. Now, thanks to the invasion of the motor car, the man of fashion, who in former days was at the inert y of a skeleton cocotte and her bibulous master, and who at six o'clock found that his list of absolutely necessary visits was not half exhausted, will manage to got through his duties with less wear and tear.

There is something excruciatingly funny to the smiling philosopher in the demands of New Year's Day upon the Paris man of fashion, for the whole thing is so gloriously artificial. He has provided himself with a load of sweets prettily made up in satin bags, each bag marked with the name of a well-known firm. This does not of necessity imply that the sweets have been bought at the good -and expensive - establishment the name of which figures in golden letters on the bag, for other firms will supply named bugs at a trilling charge.

At every house where be has dined during the year the man of fashion must pay a call. He dashes out of his car, runs in, bag in hand, murmurs a few compliments over Madame's hand, kisses it, and flies. Madame, who, if be has given her time, has protested that sweets from — are the only ones for which she cares, puts the bag on a little table and the card on another. At intervals during the afternoon her husband, who is also flying round Paris on a round of sweet-delivering, drops in to replenish his supply of bonbons, so that the same bag travels right round a circle of acquaintances, and very often ands where it began. Still, fashion has its bye laws, and these must be observed. Nobody would dream of establishing a clearing-house for New Year's sweets and compliments and spending the day in tie country, although I dare say a good many Parisians would like to.

The National Assembly, composed of the Senate and the Chamber of Deputies, sitting together, will meet to elect the new President of the Republic on January 15, or 16, instead of the 18th, the date originally mentioned, the experts in constitutional law having printed out that M. Loubet's powers expire on February 18, and that his successor must be elected at least one month before then. To be on the safe side, therefore, the date will be altered. It is a curious fact that since the present Constitution has been in force, some 30 years, no President has ever been in office at the moment his successor was elected. With the exception of M. Loubet, only M. Grévy completed his seven years' term, and as he was re elected, there was no transmission of power. M. Carnot and M. Félix Faure died in harness. M. Casimir-Perier resigned, as did also M. Grévy during his second term. So that France bas never experienced the sensation of having two Presidents at the same time, as she will do this year between January 16 and February 18. As a matter of fact the President elected in January will only be President-Designate, and will remain an ordinary citizen until at the appointed time he is invested by his predecessor with the ruling power.

All of the three most likely candidates for the Presidency, M. Fallières, M. Doumer, and M. Léon Bourgeois, are freemasons, and therefore the Clerical party, in voting for M. Doumer, will be giving its support to a man, who, in the eyes of the Church, is prescribed. It would be interesting to know what pledges have been given to salve its conscience.

There are signs that Germany is contemplating a return to more gracious methods in her dealings with France. If that be so, the change will be due, first, to the discovery that bullying was only momentarily successful, and failed after it had brought down M. Delcassé ; secondly, to consciousness that the French army is quite ready to give a good account of itself ; and, thirdly, to a plain intimation from Downing Street that there is no change in British policy.

Some time ego the "Echo de Paris" sent one of its staff to Berlin to report on Carman opinion on France and French foreign policy. The first results of his investigations were published yesterday in the form of conversations with Prince von Arenberg and Count von Reventlow, the leaders respectively of the Centre party in the Reichstag and the pan- Germanic movement, prefaced by the editor's remark that be does not necessarily fall in with the views recorded. No wonder he felt bound to make a reservation, the following being, according to Count von Reventlow, the pan Germanic dream of Empire :—All the Moorish coast line and hinterland, as well as Bohemia and Hungary, with a diminished Austria as a vassal State under a German Prince ; Trieste, of courre, and the Adriatic littoral, Luxembourg, and Holland, and Belgium. Outside Europe pan-Gemans aspire to Brazil in the western hemisphere, and Mesopotamia as a foothold in Asia. When it was suggested to Count von Reventlow that the rest of be world might object to this drastic alteration of the map, he said :— "We shall see. In any case we do not fear France."

Prince von Arenberg and his party are more moderate in their demands than the "whole-hoggers" of the pan-Germanic type. Germany, must have, he says, sea bases and coal depots along the highways of the world. She has no intention of robbing any one, but of the waste spaces still to be conquered and organised she demands her share. "We have ships," he said, "on every sea, the fastest and finest mail steamers afloat, and we must have Gorman ports for thorn to go to. Salt water is common properly, and the Mediterranean and the Atlantic cannot be closed to us." The German Emperor, Prince von Arenberg said, is the most sincerely peaceful man be knows, and that only his care for the vital interests of Gorman commerce made him decide to go to Tangier and raise the Morocco difficulty. As the Prince twitted the French Press with having "a terrible imagination," it must be assumed that he had no knowledge of the conversation with Count von Reventlow.

France, according to the rules of sound economy, ought to be drifting towards bankruptcy. She employs the deadliest of all forms of Protection—the bounty system—to keep her works and mills running. But she has not been guilty of the most fatal mistake of all, of letting her land go out of cultivation. And that is the simple reason why France has no unemployed. Her people still till the fields and grow food for the townsmen instead of Hocking into the cities to take the bread out of their mouths. In an article in the "République Française " yesterday morning, M. Méline says that there is only one real solution to the unemployed problem in England ; the surplus labourers must be got back to the land, from which they ought never to have been al owed to stray. He admits that the re-conversion of town labourers into farmers is no easy matter, but thinks that it-may be done gradually by inculcating in them a love of the soil. He suggests that the Queen's Fund and ail the resources of the State and private charity should be devoted to providing working men with gardens. When once they learn what the soil will do, some, at least, he thinks, will be drawn back to it, and the balance of supply and demand in labour will be gradually restored.

From the annual report of the National Savings Banks in Franco, which has just appeared for the year 1904, it is apparent that the French instinct for saving is in no danger of being eradicated. The forward movement which met with a temporary check in 1902-3, resumed its normal course in the year under consideration. In 1903 the withdrawals exceeded the deposits by nearly £610,000, but in 1904 very much the contrary was the case, the deposits showing a balance over withdrawals of £1,640,000. The number of deposit kooks issued numbered 4,345,446, an increase of 201,558 over the previous year. At the close of 1904 the total amount of money deposited was £47,393,920, the highest figure reached since the foundation of the institution; and a convincing proof of the confidence of the public in the soundness of the concern.

In Paris, the city of tasteful luxury and refined extravagance, toys are to the children what more costly follies are to the elder folk. Therefore, Paris is the home of elaborate toys. "Tell me what playthings you give to your children, and I will tell you what you are bringing them up to be." If the parents are dumb, the shop windows answer. Every year toys get more elaborate, more costly, more typical of the life of wealthy Paris. The girls still want dolls, but not the modest poppets their mothers played with and dressed themselves. They must be as big as a good sized child, and possess half a dozen toilettes packed in a trunk large enough to hold a man's wardrobe.

The clothes must be cut after the latest model, and made of the most fashionable and expensive material. Boys used to get boxes of tools, but now, if they condescend to utilitarian tastes at all, they are given a manufactory in miniature, with electric motors to drive the machines. Generally, however, they want motor-cars or mail coaches, air ships, or shooting outfits, but, most of all weapons.

Caire, 4 janvier.

Londres none transmet encore des conn très fermes Bien que le Consolidé anglais et l'Unifiée soient renseignés en légère réaotion, les valeurs égyptiennes poursuivent leur mouvement ascensionnel ; arnri la National Bank a gagné 5/8 de livre à 26 1/2, la Daïra ¼ a 17 3/4 et l'Agricole 1/4 à 9 3/4.
A Paris, l'action Créùit Foncier est revenue à 801, après la hausse de 31 francs acquise dans la séanoe précédente.

Ici, ce matin, le marché des valeurs présente enoore une certaine animation. La National a été très soutenue à 26 3/16 avec de nombreuses s flaires. L'Agricole a clôturé ferme à 9 11/16. L'action Crédit Fonciera ouvert h 800 pour finir à 804, aveo de forte acheteurs ; les obligations 1886 ont progressé h 836 et les nouvelles à 974. La Daïts s'est iniorite h 17 11/16. Le Banque d'Abyssinie a coté 7 1/8 vendeurs. Le Comptoir Financier a avancé 4 8/a
L'action Bourse -Khédiviale do Caire a enoore gagné £90 à 180. La part de fondateur Agricole do Nil a sauté de 4 1/2 à 5 1/8. La Delta Light a monté k 12 1/4 et la Delta Land 2 3/16 acheteurs.

Dans le groupa des Hâtais, les Nungovioh sont faibles à 11 11/16. Par ooutre, le» Baehler montent a 3 9/16 et lee Upper Egypt à 5 5/16. Les Splendid et les National te maintiennent leurs prix précédents.
Les petites valeurs sont calmes.

Nous apprenons que la Land Allotment Company vient de condors l'achat d'une propriété de 1,500 fed dans, sise à Damanhour, an prix de £100,000, soit environ £70 le feddan. On dit que c'est une bonne affaire

On none informe que l'Egyptian Estâtes Company vient de conclure une fort belle affaire à Tantah. Ella a acheté 20 feddans sur le canal Gaafarieh. le nouveau quartier fashionable de 1a ville, à £ 1000 le faddan, soit on pen plus de P.E. 20 le mètre.
Or, des personnes bien renseignées affirment qu'on pourrait immédiatement revendre ces terrains à raison de P.E. 50 a 100 le mètre.
Si l'information était exaote, oe serait lk an profit éventuel d'une trentaine de mille livrée.
Nous recevons d'Alexandrie des renseignements intéressants sur lee Splendid Hotels.

Le transformation do New Khédivial touche à sa fin, et bientôt l'hâtel disposera de 150 chambres. En attendant, les recettes vont aog. mentant ; l'hâtel effectue un surplus de recettes de 40 à 50 livras par jour. Ce aurcroit im portant de reveon mérite d'ètre pria en considération, vu que le capital de la Société n'est que de LE. 90,000, divisé en 22,500 actions, et qu'il n'y a ni parts de fondateur, ni obligations.
La Compagnie des Omnibus do Caire convoque ses actionnaires en assemblée générale extraordinaire poor le 16 do mois courant.

L'assemblée aura à sanctionner un projet de fusion aveo one Sooiété en voie de formation la "Borié'é des transporte automobiles du Caire" Cette Société se constitue au capital de £ 100,000, eu 25,000 actions de £ 4.
Cheque action de la Compagnie des Omnibus sera éobangée contre 3 1/4 actions de la Société des transporte automobiles.
Les cours du ooton sont arrivés en hausse d'Amériqne. Hier, le dieponible a gagné 10 points, le Janvier et le Mai 8 points respectivement Liverpool eat également en repriee.
Les arrivages ont été restreints : 29,000 balles contre 49,000.
Ici, la Mars a ouvert ce matin, a 16 21/32 pour clôturer au même prix.

M. M. H. de Vries at Bontigny, agente de change, ta chargent de l'exécution de tous ordres de Bonne (valeurs et marchandises) sur las marchés de Londres, Parie, Bruxelles, An vert, Liverpool et New-York. La Circulaire quotidienne de la maison est envoyée sur demande.

div.head: SUCRIES ET RAFFINERIE D'EGYPTE
div.p: ASSEMBLÉE GÉNÉRALE DES OBLIGATAIRES
(Suite et fin de la discussion.)

UN OBLIGATAIRE. — Je commence d'abord par remercier le Comité d'avoir rejeté le projet des contrôleur,», contraire à nos intérêts. Et j'entre dans la question des poursuites envers les administrateurs. M. Lacombe disait tont A l'heare qne l'Association Nationale ne pouvait pas soutenir les actions individuelles Ce pointr me semble juste. Mais l'Association a été créée pour soutenir l'intérét des porteurs. Il y a ici un oas général : c'ait celui des escroqueries et des vols oommis b notre détriment, qui sont justiciables de la juridiction correctionnelle. L'Assooiation pourrait se joindre an groupe d'actionnaires qui a déposé une plainte an parqneb Et si leparqnetet le Juge d'ins traction déclarent oonpables les administrateurs, nous pourrons nous porter partie civile, et l'Assooia tien pourra nous réanir pour payer notre part de cotisation afin de p ycr les poursuites.
None pourrons alors faire valoir individuel lament nos droits à la réparation du préjudice causé.

Je orois que la Société Générale pourrait être rendue responsable, tout au moins en la personne de son Directeur. Ses employés ont donné des renseignements inexacts, et le? tribunaux pourraient examiner jusqu'à quel point la Sooiété Générale est responsable do ses représentants.
On nous a parlé de noos accorder 2 %. J'estime qne si nous sommes obligés do faite un sacrifice, il devrait être au maximum do 100 francs par obligation, payable de la manière suivante :

Les obligations actuelles seraient transformées en obligations 3 % 400 francs, avec première hypothèque sur tout l'actif social, à l'exception des domaines achetés à la Daira Sanieh. Au cas oh la Société serait remise sur pied, il nous serait donné une action de 100 francs, qui prendrait rang aprè» les actions actuelles. L'amortissement serait suspendn pendant cinq ans. J'estime que c'est là le maximum de concessions que nous pourrons faire.
UN OBLIGATAIRE — Quelle serait la situation des Obligataires, en admettant qu'il y ait faillite t Quels avantages pourrions-nous retirer d'un arrangementlQue pourrions noos toucher!
M. LACOUBE — C'est là, en effa', la queition la plus importante et on pourrait la qualifier de préjudiciable ; je vais y répondre.

Il y a un point sur lequel je me proposai» d'être robre de détails, parce que je ne voulais pas fournir des arguments à ceux qui vans pré senteraient un projet d'arrangement onéreox : c'e«t celui des coneéquenoes probables de 1a faillite.

Vous pavez œ qu'est une usine à sucre. Elle peut valoir beauooup, mais seulement à la condition qoel'oh pourra continuer la fabrication, car si l'industrie doit cesser, il faut vendre les bâtiments à un prix inférieur, et les appareils et machines se vendront également au prix du vieux matériel. Si les experts ont pu les évaluer h on prix assez élevé, c'est dans la prévision qu'elles continueraient à fonctionner.

Sans doute, si oes usines étaient dans la ré gion du t ord de la Frapoe, on pourrait espérer trouver toojonrs un acqoéreor à un prix rai sonnable. En Egypte, il n'y a pas à prévoir de oonourrence entre acquéreurs. Si vous ne faites pas un concordat qui poisse assurer le relèvement de l'affaire, vous verrez que l'aotif serv aobeté à vil prix par un groupe qui réalisera de» bénéfices énormes au préjudice des oréan oiers actuels.

Ce qu'il importe, avant tont, ce n'est pas tant oe qn'on promettra aux obligataires par le oonoordat, o'est ce qu'il adviendra de l'affaire Le Comité s'est donc préoonppé principalement de ce qui pouvait assurer une sérieuse réorganisation. Le projet présenté par la Société ne Ini donne pas à ce point de vue de garanties suffisantes; car l'Adminis ration resterait entre les mains d'actionnaires qui n'ont pas d'in'érêt à bien gérer. Voilà pourquoi, dès le premier jour, nous avons appnyé, sauf à l'amender snr certains points, le projet de reconstitution q i émane d'> n groupe financier sérieox.

D'après ce projet, à vous Obligataires, on donnera des obligations à revenu variable mais l'affaire sera réorganisée, et s'appuiera désormais, sur le groupe des porteurs d'actions privilégiées, groupe qui comprendra les plus grandes maisons financières de Paris.
DES VOIX. — Lesquelles 1

M. LACOMBE — Ce sont les porteurs de traite dont je parle ; vous savez qne, parmi eux se trouvent plusieurs barques de premier ordre. Ces futurs actionnaires se trouvent dans uno telle situation, que, l-r-qne U Société aura besoin de fonds, i's n'auront pas de peili1' à trouver les conooors nécessaire?. Parmi eux, je otnprenda la Sociéré Générale elle même, et il est à souhaiter qne le groupe de la Daira Sugar figure parmi ces ooncours, parce qo cela augmentera les chance» qne voua avez d'obtenir du Gouvernement Egyptien les oon cesMnnn qne nous attendons de lui.
UN Obligataire - Le contrat de la Daira Su car est-il valable 1

M. LACOMBE — Notre avocat du Caire nous l'a dée'aré tel. Mais, de tonte façon, il taot i'iv cepter, car la reconstitution de l'affaire repose, en grande partie, sur des concessions du G luvornement Egyptien, qne vous obt'edrft pins f cilemrnt si l'élément anglo-égyptien est , inlériM-é à l'entreprise.

Four qne le service des obligations soit ii Miré, que faut-il f Un bénéfice de 3,200,000 fr par an. Nous pensons qu'aveole? oonronrs dont nous parlons, r-e chiffre pourra être obtenu ; en tons cas, affirmer que d'ici quelques années il ■ e le sera pas, o'eat tffi-mor une chose que l'on ni sait pas. Quoi qu'il en soit, l'ix érience j na rao'.el.'e pas la peine d'ê're tentée? Evi- d u unnt si, et LOUS ne v yons pas pourquoi foui ne e f.riez pat, puisqu'elle ne vont fait pas perdre vos rcconrs et que vous seriez toujours à temps de les faire valoir, peut-être même avec d autant plus de force que vous aurez fait tout votre possible pour restreindre Il préjudice éprouvé.

UN Obligataire. — De qui émane le deu- x'ème projet I Est il officieux on officiel 1 A-t il des ohances d'aboutir i M. Lacoube. — Il est officieux ; il émane d'un groupe financier, notamment du groupe anglo-égyptien dont il a été parlé. Nos pourparlers arec la Société tendent à faire substituer œ projet à l'autre comme base de discussion. Nos raisons nous paraissent tellement convaincantes, que nous croyons avoir de eé rieuses chance» d'aboutir à co premier résultat.
UN Obligataire. — Avant de passer au vote, voudriez vous relire le projet officieux ?

M. LACOMBE — Ce projet dit qo'il sera fait une émission d'ob'igatiom hypothécaires de 800.000 livres ; les obligations actuelles seront réduites de 20 % et deviendront variables. Les porteurs de traites, recevant dos notions privilégiées, ne viendraient pas en concurrence avec Iss Obligataires. Pendant les trois premières années, il serait servi à ces derniers un intérêt fixe garanti de dix franos. Il est vrai qn'on ne nous a offert jusqu'ici que 7 fr. 50.
UN Obligataire — Les Obligataires au raient-ils le droit de préférence dans la souscription des nouvelles obligations bypothé caires ?

M. LACOMBE. — S'il est réclamé, il sera sans doute volontiers aooordé. Au sujet de la réduction du capital nominal des obligations, tonten maintenant leur intérêt et leur amortissement au taux aotuel, ce n'est qu'uue question de omptab lité tendant à équilibrer le bilan La durée de l'amortissement est fixée à 50 ans.

Nous faisons tous nos efforts poor ramener la Société à ce projet, autant pour éviter anx Obligataires, la concurrence des porteurs de traites, q .'afin de pouvoir compter sur eux pour assurer à l'affaire une bonne direction.

UN Obligataire. — Aurons-nous une qnote part de fonds provenant de la vente Cronier t M. Lacombe — Noua n'avons pu étndié spécialement cette question. On ne pourrait enc .re former saisie-arrêt sur cette somme ; il faudrait d'abord obteuir ud j ugement constatant le droit de oréanoe. C'est nue question dont le Comité pourra se préoccuper.
Un OBLIGATAIRE' — Le Comité ne pourrait- il pu inviter les représentants de 1a Sooiété en Egypte à faire cette saisie ?
M. LACOMBE. — Le Comité soumettra cetta question à ses Conseils du Caire.
Un OBLIGATAIRE. — Je me demande s'il n'y aurait pas intérêt à envisager la possibilité d'nDe liquidation ?

Notre Comité devrait faire étudier la question de savoir si l'on ne pourrait pu obtenir des Tribunaux égyptiens de nous faire passer avant les porteurs de traites ? Dans le cas contraire, nous aurions intérêt à dire : si les porteurs de traites ne veulent pu faire un sacrifice beaucoup plus grand que celui qu'on nous demande, tant pis pour eux, et l'on procédera à la liquidation.

M. LACOMBE. — Nous avons posé cette question de droit commercial égyptien à M. Saint- Plancat, qui nous a répondu qu'il n'y avait pu légalement de difiérenoes entre les porteurs de traites et les Obligataires, sous réserve de l'examen de choque oréanoe devant le Tribunal. Mais, en dehors du droit striot, il y a les pourparlers amiables, grâce auxquels nous espérons pouvoir faire passer les porteurs de traites après tes Obligataires.

Un Obligataire. — Pour que nous puissions exercer faction sociale ou les actions individuelles dont on a parlé tont à l'hsure, et pour pouvoir nous grouper dans ce but, il importe que nous nous connaissions. Je deman de donc qu'nne liste des adhérants nous soit communiquée par l'Assoeiation,

M. LACOMBE. - ,'edois dire que l'Association a déclaré expr esté ment, lors de sa fondation, que pour tous les renreiguements qui lui seraient donnés par les porteurs sur les valeurs qa'ils possèdent, elle se considérait oomme tenue par le secret professionnel.

M. LE PRESIDENT. — La discussion étant terminée, et vu l'impossibilité de prendre une décision défiuitive en oe moment sur les propositions concordataires, je vous invite à voter simplemeut les trois résolutions suivantes :

Ire RESOLUTION Les Ooligataires de la Société Générale des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte réunis en Assemblée Générale par les soins de Association Nationale des porteurs Français de valeurs étrangères approuvent le rapport présenté par la Comité de Défense et invitent le Comité à continuer ses démarches en vne d'arriver à un accord sur les bases et sous réserve des amendements indiqués au rapport.
Cette résolution est votée à l'unanimité moins cinq voix.
2me RESOLUTION

Les obligataires approuvant les démarches déjà faites auprès du Gouvernement Françria, invitent l'Association Nationale et le Comité de Défmse à les otntiuuer, en vue d'obtenir du Gouvernement Egyptien l'adoption des mesures les plus propres à favoriser le relèvement de ,'inluscrie sucrière en Egypte.
3me RESOLUTION

L'Assemblée invite le Comité à transmettre immédiatement à M. le Juge-Commis, Présidant de U Chambre Commerciale du Caire, les résolutions de l'Assemblée et à lni demander d'ao- oorder les délais suffisants pour permettre aux négociations de se poursuivre.
Ces deux dernières résolutions sont votées a l'onaoimité.
